elements.title: H. J. Lovink Pumping Station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the H. J. Lovink Pumping Station (pictured), a national monument of the Netherlands, was used to reclaim the Flevopolder?

elements.title: 1899–1900 peasant unrest in Bulgaria (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that during the 1899–1900 peasant unrest in Bulgaria, some troops refused orders to fire on the protesters?

elements.title: the winner (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the winner of the seventeenth series of Britain's Got Talent was the first individual woman to win the show without a dog?

elements.title: Pinxton Castle (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the moat around Pinxton Castle was inside the perimeter walls, rather than outside?

elements.title: William Beck (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that William Beck emigrated to the US from Germany, became a policeman at 19, was wounded by a Native American tribe, and was shipwrecked before becoming Milwaukee's first police chief?

elements.title: a Texas TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a Texas TV station hoped that being named after an eye would ease viewer confusion?

elements.title: Pharos (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Pharos, the largest impact crater on Neptune's moon Proteus, is more than half the diameter of Proteus itself?

elements.title: How to Be Perfect (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in his book How to Be Perfect, Michael Schur sought to "wade into some deeply confusing and painful applications of moral philosophy ... but in a fun way"?

elements.title: ML Buch (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a video accompanying ML Buch's debut album showed viewers her inner self – literally?
